McLeary (2016) states that: Iran says it has dispatched two warships to the Gulf of Aden to ply the same waters as several U.S. Navy vessels are already operating there, one of which launched several Tomahawk missiles at Tehran-backed Houthi radar installations early Thursday morning.
According to the Iranian Tasnim news site, which has links to the Iranian Revolutionary Guards Corps, the frigate Alvand and logistics ship Bushehr are heading to the Yemeni coast “to protect the country’s trade vessels against piracy.” But the site also notes that “the presence of the Iranian fleet in the Gulf of Aden coincides with the US decision to directly get involved in a Saudi-led war against Yemen.” Piracy has all but disappeared in the area, and the Iranian ships are scheduled to then sail south down Africa’s east 
The Iranian warship heading to the Gulf of Aden — the 45 year-old Alvand, which carries anti-ship missiles, a Mark 8 gun as well as various machine guns — already has a checkered history with the U.S. Navy. In July 2015, the ship trained its guns on a U.S. Navy helicopter and an allied supply ship operating with the USS Farragut in the waterway, but the incident was contained before any violence broke out.
The news of the deployment comes hours after the USS Nitze launched several Tomahawk missiles at three radar sites in a Houthi rebel-controlled part of Yemen, sites the U.S. believes took part in the three separate missile attacks on U.S. Navy ships operating off the Yemeni coast this week.
Yemen’s Saba news agency, which acts as a mouthpiece for the Houthi-led government, charged Thursday that “U.S. allegations” of its ships being targeted were made to create “false justifications to pave the way for Saudi-led coalition to escalate their aggression” against Yemen “and to cover for crimes continually committed” by the coalition fighting to oust the Houthis from power (para. 1-5). Author Fandos (2016) states that: WASHINGTON — The $12 million compound, once a playground for the Iranian ambassador and guests like Elizabeth Taylor, Andy Warhol and Richard M. Nixon, now sits empty on Washington’s Embassy Row.
The five-story Upper East Side townhouse that served as a consulate was long ago repurposed as the headquarters of a dealer of old master paintings.
And the seven-bedroom Bethesda, Md., ranch house for Iranian diplomats is now the home of a family of five.
The properties, and seven others across the United States assessed altogether at more than $50 million, still belong to the Islamic Republic ofIran. But for nearly 40 years, the task of maintaining and putting the properties out for rent has fallen to an unlikely management company — the State Department.
The arrangement is one of the stranger consequences of the diplomatic freeze between United States and Iran, two former allies that cut official ties after Iranian revolutionaries took 52 Americans hostage in the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979. Although much has changed since the nuclear deal last year, when Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief, experts say Iran and the United States are still years away from re-establishing diplomatic relations (para. 1-5). Author Fleitz, (2016) states that: On Monday, International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) director general Yukiya Amano explained what had up to this point been a mystery: namely, why its recent reports on Iran’s nuclear program have been so vague and contain such little data. As it turns out, under the Iran nuclear deal or Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), there are now limitations on what the IAEA is allowed to report. According to Amano, due to new U.N. Security Council and IAEA resolutions, the agency will only monitor and verify Iran’s compliance with its JCPOA commitments and will no longer provide broad reporting on its nuclear program. A December 15, 2015, IAEA Board of Governors resolution directed the organization to cease reporting on Iran’s compliance with its Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty obligations and past Security Council resolutions because the Board of Governors is no longer seized of this matter (para 1). JCPOA Exemptions Revealed September 1, 2016
The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) placed detailed limitations on facets of Iran’s nuclear program that needed to be met by Implementation Day, which took place on January 16, 2016.* Most of the conditions were met by Iran. However, we have learned that some nuclear stocks and facilities were not in accordance with JCPOA limits on Implementation Day, but in anticipation the Joint Commission had earlier and secretly exempted them from the JCPOA limits. The exemptions and in one case, a loophole, involved the low enriched uranium (LEU) cap of 300 kilograms (kg), some of the near 20 percent LEU, the heavy water cap, and the number of large hot cells allowed to remain in Iran. One senior knowledgeable official stated that if the Joint Commission had not acted to create these exemptions, some of Iran’s nuclear facilities would not have been in compliance with the JCPOA by Implementation Day. While majorities continue to support trade, academic, cultural, sports and tourist exchanges with the United States, overall, 72.9% of Iranians have an unfavorable view of the United States, compared to 66.6% a year ago.
A majority of 54% now opposes military cooperation with the United States against the group that calls itself the Islamic State — a reversal from the 59% who favored such cooperation after the JCPOA was signed.

There are five main reasons why the US would open an embassy or consulate in Iran before October 2016: 1. To improve diplomatic relations. Despite a tentative warming in relations between Iran and the West, it seems unlikely that the US has much to gain from opening an embassy in Iran. Although it is true that Obama has normalised relations with Cuba, there are compelling circumstances (geography; a large Cuban-American population; open relations between Cuba and various US allies; Cuba not posing a military threat) which do not apply in the Iranian situation (Iran is far away from the US; the Iranian-American population is relatively small and politically insignificant; relations between Iran and key US allies, particularly Israel, are strained or hostile; Iran poses a potential military threat, and has acted against US interests in the Persian Gulf several times in the last three years). Trade between the US and Iran is minimal, and there are no pressing reasons for Obama to want to accelerate the current thaw. 2. To provide consular services to US citizens. There is little need for this - the US advises its citizens against travel to Iran, and consular services are provided via the Swiss embassy. Best estimates suggest that there are only a very small number (generally ranging from dozens to a few hundred) of US citizens in Iran at any one time (although these figures do not account for those with dual nationality). 3. To provide a base for intelligence gathering. However, a physical embassy or consulate would become an immediate target for Iranian counter-intelligence and would likely damage rather than enhance US intelligence-gathering operations in Iran. Although reliable evidence in this area is (for obvious reasons) hard to come by, there is reason to think that, while there are US intelligence networks in Iran, the US relies to a much greater extent on intelligence passed on from allies, particularly Israel. 4. A way for Obama to make life difficult for a potential Republican successor. Given his statements about Islam generally, and about tearing up the Iran nuclear deal in particular, it may be embarrassing for Donald Trump, were he to become president, to have to oversee a new US embassy in Iran. He would likely act to close it soon after coming to power. There is an outside chance, therefore, that Obama may seek to open an Iranian embassy or consulate in order to inconvenience Trump. This is, however, an extremely slim chance: an Iranian embassy would pose similar problems for Clinton as it would for Trump; and the risks to US standing abroad would likely outweigh the modest political benefits. At any rate, those who support Trump would likely approve of any action he took against Iran; closing a hypothetical embassy there would probably *gain* him political support domestically.  5. To act as a centre for the promotion of American culture and values in Iran. However, the nature of the Iranian regime makes the promotion of American culture and values at best very difficult, and at worst illegal. It is likely that the embassy would be the subject of intensive surveillance by the Iranians, and the identities of those going to events there would be known to the authorities. This, along with the repressive and controlling nature of the Iranian regime, and the general unpopularity of the United States in a country where it has been relentlessly demonised for more than three decades, would severely hamper the embassy's cultural power. Actively promoting American values in Iran (a country where the last US embassy was violently stormed and hostages were taken) would also put embassy staff at risk which, given that the Obama administration is highly sensitive to the security of its embassy staff following the murder of the US ambassador in Lybia, makes this possibility even more unlikely. Therefore, it seems that the chances of the Obama administration opening an embassy in Iran before October 18th are extremely slim.

I think this is very unlikely. On the one hand, opening an Embassy or consulate would be a powerful symbolic step for the Obama administration, and a signal that the administration's standing behind its signature foreign-policy achievement. On the other hand, as @Amir- points out the safety of the consulate is a key concern, particularly given the original reason for the break in diplomatic relations. Concern about the safety of diplomats has only been heightened as the death of Ambassador Christopher Stevens in Benghazi. The attack on the Saudi Embassy in Iran in January indicates that the Iranian government remains unable/unwilling to insure the safety of foreign diplomatic personnel, so it seems unlikely that the US Embassy or consulate were open in the near future. Additionally, remaining US sanctions would make it  difficult for the US government to buy/rent property in Tehran or hire local contractors or employees. I suppose OFAC could grant the state department a waiver, but it seems likely that the remaining sanctions will need to go first, and that will depend on Congress. I'm giving yes 5% chance, however, since it is possible that the Obama administration could announce the opening of an Embassy or consulate scheduled sometime in the relatively distant future, e.g. 2019, gaining the symbolic victory, while not taking any risk.

The base rate here must be very low. Let's try to get a handle on it. Imagine that at some time T in the future the U.S. reopens the Iranian embassy. So from Nov 1979 to T, there was no U.S. embassy in Tehran; call this the embassyless period. Without access to any knowledge about anything, we must assume the present moment (Apr 2016) is a random time in the embassyless period. If an embassy is created by 18 Oct 2016, right now will have turned out to be in the last 1.3% of the embassyless period; and since now is a random time, the odds that it falls within the final 1.3% of the embassyless period must be 1.3%.  Another base rate may be gleaned from Cuba. The U.S. and Cuba severed relations in 1961, and an American embassy in Cuba was recreated only in 2015, so 54 years. Let's say that's the average amount of time. The U.S. and Iran fell out in 1979; even if we assume a very fat tailed-distribution with standard deviation of 10 years, that still makes for only 4% odds of an American embassy in Tehran a mere 37 years after the falling out. There has been a nuclear deal of some kind recently (I don't know the details) but I feel it has become politically toxic in the U.S. I don't see why any politician would stick their neck out to suggest an embassy in Tehran. Obama would have to go there like he did with Cuba, play nice and shake hands, why would he do that just before the elections? Suicide for the Democrats. I'm calling this one a 0%. P.S. Rereading the question I noticed I interpreted it as "will the embassy actually open by 18 Oct 2016", but it's actually just about the announcement. Still, as it turns out, the announcement of the Cuban embassy preceded the actual opening by less than a month. And the electoral effects of announcement would probably not be so different from the opening. So I'm maintaining the forecast.

One relevant case study might concern the restoration of US dip rels with Saddam Hussain's Iraq (broken in 1967) in 1984, during the Iran-Iraq war, and also a US election year. The key point of note being that diplomatic relations were not restored until (and shortly after) the US Presidential election had concluded: in late November. The website of the Wilson Center includes the text of a then, top secret document  http://digitalarchive.wilsoncenter.org/document/122544 that contains the following sentences, which appear to have some features in common with the present US outlook towards Iran: "For a long time the Iraqi leadership had taken great pains to prepare for the restoration of diplomatic relations with the United States on 26 November 1984. The timing of the renewal of relations coincided with the reelection of President Reagan that according to some views will ensure some continuity in the foreign policy of the United States. Naturally, this policy also includes the Middle Eastern policy of the USA that had ended in repeated failures during the first term of Reagan’s presidency in Lebanon and brought the Camp David process to a deadlock. Therefore the republican government of the United States had to “freeze” its political activities in the Middle East in the year of the election so that it could erase the past of several blunders committed by the Reagan administration in the region. However, from the beginning of 1984 it became clear even in this “state of rest” that American foreign policy showed more “understanding” towards the Iraqi position both officially and through the press. This process eventually led to the restoration of diplomatic relations between the two countries." One can attempt to draw numerous parallels with the present situation vis a vis Iran....- -but the looming prospect of a US presidential election surely towers over all else.
